author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Even in Texas, You Can’t Stop the Green Revolution
description: Over the past few weeks, a once unthinkable parable about the green transition has played out in Texas, the very picture of a recalcitrant red state soaked with fossil fuel. Legislators friendly to the oil and gas business staged a desperate fight with the market — and lost.
content: Over the past few weeks, a once unthinkable parable about the green transition has played out in Texas, the very picture of a recalcitrant red state soaked with fossil fuel. Legislators friendly to the oil and gas business staged a desperate fight with the market — and lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: This Extinct Dolphin Had Tusks That Fish Were Wise to Avoid
description: The snaggletoothed cetacean used teeth projected from its snout to stun prey, much like modern sawfish do.
content: The waters off New Zealand 25 million years ago were home to early baleen whales, megatooth sharks and human-size penguins. Now researchers are adding a bizarre dolphin to the mix that may have used tusklike teeth to thrash prey into submission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive: What to Know
description: The Ukrainians are now on the offense. But measuring their progress is difficult this early on.
content: Even President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine now says so: The country’s long-awaited counteroffensive to retake Russian-occupied territory has begun. After months of defending against a barrage of airstrikes, Ukraine is on the offense, looking for vulnerabilities along the 600-mile front line and even launching strikes on Russian soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: How Trump’s Aide Came to Be Charged as a Co-Conspirator, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: How Yotam Ottolenghi Comes Up With a New Recipe
description: Familiar ingredients — peppers, eggplants, tomatoes — lay the foundation for creations like this Moroccan dip.
content: I was flipping through Niki Segnit’s new book, “The Flavor Thesaurus: More Flavors,” as I was making this recipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Martell
title: A Rare Matchup of Aces Adds ‘Extra Buzz’ to Subway Series
description: Gerrit Cole and Justin Verlander have dominated baseball for years, and were teammates in Houston. On Wednesday they will face each other for only the second time.
content: Nearly eight years ago, the Pittsburgh Pirates began a three-game series on the road against the Detroit Tigers with a 5-4 win in 14 innings. Aside from being the longest game ever played at Comerica Park, at 5 hours 30 minutes, that extra-inning slog is also the only game to feature a starting pitching matchup between Gerrit Cole and Justin Verlander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto, Pat McCusker and Diane Wong
title: For a 30-Year-Old Virgin, It’s Now or Never
description: Clare Almand thinks her days are numbered. She decides it’s time to have sex — as soon as possible.
content: Clare Almand was born with congenital heart disease, so her life was never what she would call “normal.” By the time she was 30, she’d had 10 open-heart surgeries and her health was rapidly declining. Clare thought she was dying.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christian Cooper and Amy Tan on How Birding Brings Them Joy: a Live Event
description: The two will discuss their shared love of birding in a free live virtual event as part of The New York Times summer birding project.
content: Sign up for this free live-streamed event, Thursday, June 22, 1 p.m. Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: Talks in Turkey on Sweden’s bid to join NATO end with no progress reported.
description: Turkey wants a tougher stance from Stockholm toward pro-Kurdish activists and members of an outlawed religious group whom Turkey considers terrorists.
content: ISTANBUL — High-level talks on Wednesday in Turkey aimed at bridging differences over Sweden’s application to join NATO ended with no progress being announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Thomas Fuller
title: Westfield Gives Up San Francisco Mall, Signaling More Pain Ahead
description: Retailers have been fleeing the city’s downtown, and some analysts say there may be more to come. It’s an issue facing various downtowns around the United States.
content: Nordstrom. Old Navy. Anthropologie. H&M. Crate & Barrel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Hoping to Avert Nuclear Crisis, U.S. Seeks Informal Agreement With Iran
description: The talks reflect a resumption of diplomacy between the United States and Iran after the collapse of negotiations to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
content: The Biden administration has been negotiating quietly with Iran to limit Tehran’s nuclear program and free imprisoned Americans, according to officials from three countries, in part of a larger U.S. effort to ease tensions and reduce the risk of a military confrontation with the Islamic Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What Higher Interest Rates Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: After raising interest rates 10 times over the past 15 months, the Federal Reserve took a break on Wednesday and held rates steady — at least for the moment. But the cumulative effects of past rate increases will continue to squeeze the budgets of debt-laden Americans, while rewarding those with money to stash in savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Google Might Owe You Money. Here’s How to Get It.
description: As part of a legal settlement, Google agreed to pay $23 million to users who clicked on a search link from 2006 to 2013. Individual payments are estimated to be less than $8.
content: Anyone who clicked on a Google search result link from October 2006 to September 2013 is entitled to a piece — however small — of a $23 million settlement that the tech giant has agreed to pay to resolve a class-action lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: With Crawford-Spence, Boxing Gets a Marquee Matchup It Has Longed For
description: Crawford and Spence have talked about fighting for years. Now that they’ve agreed on a bout, they’re hoping it draws an audience beyond the usual fans of the sport.
content: As the boxers Errol Spence Jr. and Terence Crawford exchanged verbal barbs on Wednesday at the Palladium Times Square ahead of their much-delayed and anticipated bout later this summer, technicians streamed the promotional event on a billboard outside. The fighters arrived in Manhattan less than 24 hours after they participated in a similar news conference near Los Angeles at the Beverly Hills Hotel, playing up boxing’s ties to the entertainment world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: The Petronio Residency Center to Close After Six-Year Run
description: The center, an unstructured retreat for dance artists, ran into financial difficulties that were heightened by the pandemic.
content: On an idyllic spring day, the choreographer Stephen Petronio was standing in his favorite spot at the Petronio Residency Center, an elevated wooden structure that he calls the perch. With sweeping views of the Catskills and beyond, the quiet space sits on the lush, hilltop property he has transformed, over the past six years, into a retreat for choreographers and dancers, where artists can come to work — or not work — outside the usual demands of daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: At a British Amazon Warehouse, a Union Bid Surges, Then Stalls
description: Over 700 workers in Coventry joined a union and are seeking recognition for it to negotiate with the company, known for its resistance to organized labor.
content: Last summer, as Britain’s inflation rate reached 10 percent, Amazon gave its workers there a pay raise. At a warehouse in Coventry, in the Midlands of England, the offer was for an extra 50 pence (about 63 cents) an hour, or about 5 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Requires Genius and He Had It’: Readers on Cormac McCarthy
description: McCarthy’s death inspired hundreds of people to share their impressions of him and his work.
content: The death of the novelist Cormac McCarthy on Tuesday prompted an outpouring from readers, who shared favorite passages, memories of reading his books — and occasionally, encounters with the reclusive writer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Catering to a Fashionable Crowd
description: At his restaurants Sant Ambroeus and Casa Lever, Gherardo Guarducci seduces and pampers patrons. He knows they are not for everyone.
content: The panini arranged in soft mounds in the vitrine of Sant Ambroeus on Madison Avenue fairly ooze. There is the tuna, decadently layered with marinated artichoke; the pillowy frittata; the turkey stacked high with mozzarella and tomato and shellaced with Dijon mustard, all as savory looking as they are seductive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Droves of Imran Khan’s Allies Defect as Military Ramps Up Crackdown
description: More than 100 key allies of Mr. Khan have left his party in recent weeks as Pakistan’s military tries to sideline the former leader.
content: Throngs of supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan have been arrested. Media columnists considered sympathetic to him have been intimidated. Key allies have resigned from his party, saying they had been threatened with criminal charges and arrests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Jim Turner, Who Kicked the Jets Into Super Bowl History, Dies at 82
description: He was a reliable pro-football place-kicker for 16 years and had a moment of glory in the 1969 championship game.
content: Jim Turner, who fulfilled Joe Namath’s prophecy that the New York Jets would win Super Bowl III in 1969 by kicking three field goals and an extra point, making him the game’s leading scorer, died on Saturday at his home in Arvada, Colo., a suburb of Denver. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Sister-in-Law Spent All Her Parents’ Money When She Took Them In. Now She Wants More!
description: After her sister-in-law spent the money from the sale of her parents’ house on upgrades to her own, a reader bristles at being made to feel she must chip into costs for their care.
content: My husband’s elderly parents moved in with my sister-in-law. Their house was sold, and my sister-in-law used the proceeds to add a bedroom and upgrade a bathroom for them at her house. (There was an extra bedroom in the house, but no bathroom on that floor.) My husband asked my sister-in-law not to make these improvements; he suggested hiring aides to come to the house, instead. But she went ahead and spent all the money. Now, my father-in-law has been diagnosed with dementia and needs lots of additional care. We are being made to feel that we have to pitch in financially. How would you approach this dilemma?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Grand Jury Votes to Indict Daniel Penny in Subway Chokehold Killing
description: Mr. Penny, a Marine veteran, has said he was defending himself and other passengers when he choked Jordan Neely to death.
content: A grand jury on Wednesday voted to indict a Marine veteran who was arrested last month after killing a homeless man on a subway car in a case that created a political firestorm in New York City and beyond, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: The Impossible Task of Defending Donald Trump
description: Kevin McCarthy is far from alone in debasing himself for the benefit of the former president.
content: From the moment Donald Trump was indicted last week, top Republican lawmakers and media figures have found themselves in the humiliating position of trying to defend the indefensible. Many of them are lawyers; having seen the overwhelming strength of the evidence in the indictment, they could simply have accepted that Mr. Trump is in big trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Bud Light Is No Longer America’s Top-Selling Beer After Boycott
description: Bud Light lost its share of retail beer sales in recent weeks following a boycott by consumers over a promotional post by a transgender influencer.
content: Bud Light has been dethroned as the nation’s top-selling beer in recent weeks, a data analytics company said, a sign that the backlash the brewer received from conservatives over its relationship with a transgender influencer may be taking a toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Fox News Chyron Calls Biden a ‘Wannabe Dictator’
description: The onscreen text appeared Tuesday beneath split-screen footage of President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump, who had been charged with federal crimes hours earlier.
content: A Fox News chyron appeared to refer to President Biden as a “wannabe dictator” during footage of his remarks from the White House on Tuesday, the same day that former President Donald J. Trump was charged with federal crimes in a Miami courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: In This ‘Full Monty,’ the Clothes Stay On
description: A new series on Hulu and FX reunites the feel-good British film’s characters and its writer, 25 years later and in another age of austerity.
content: “‘The Full Monty’ is Sheffield, and Sheffield is ‘The Full Monty,’” said the actor Robert Carlyle in a recent video interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Generative A.I. Can Add $4.4 Trillion in Value to Global Economy, Study Says
description: The report from McKinsey comes as a debate rages over the potential economic effects of A.I.-powered chatbots on labor and the economy.
content: “Generative artificial intelligence” is set to add up to $4.4 trillion of value to the global economy annually, according to a report from McKinsey Global Institute, in what is one of the rosier predictions about the economic effects of the rapidly evolving technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: ‘It Doesn’t Count as a War Crime if You Had Fun’: Inside the Minds of Some Russian Soldiers
description: At a bar in a once-occupied Ukrainian village, dehumanizing messages on the walls were a stark reminder that the Kremlin wants to stamp out Ukraine and its culture.
content: Sweeping out discarded Russian rations, shattered glass and broken furniture was a daunting task. In the four and a half months that Russian forces had occupied a village in eastern Ukraine, the troops had used the local bar as a small outpost, gutting it in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: In San Francisco, a Week of Destination Opera
description: Audiences could take in works by Strauss and Kaija Saariaho, as well as a new one by Gabriela Lena Frank about Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera.
content: For a week this month, San Francisco was the country’s opera capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Patricia Mazzei
title: Francis Suarez, Miami Mayor, Files for a Republican Presidential Run
description: Mr. Suarez, a 45-year-old Cuban American elected overwhelmingly as mayor of Miami, is presenting himself as a fresh Republican face but faces allegations of influence peddling.
content: Mayor Francis X. Suarez of Miami filed the paperwork for a presidential campaign on Wednesday, setting him up to join an increasingly crowded field of candidates jockeying to overtake former President Donald J. Trump for the Republican nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: Mark Bradford Strikes a Pose of Quiet Self-Reflection
description: From the beauty shop to ballroom culture, the Los Angeles artist takes over Hauser & Wirth in Manhattan with a contemplative mood.
content: Mark Bradford found his way to becoming an artist while working in his mother’s beauty shop. The Los Angeles-born artist used layers of the cheap end papers — thin delicate sheets used to protect hair from burning during perming — instead of paint in the early works that would soon earn him an international reputation, eventually leading to the official United States pavilion at the 2017 Venice Biennale, his most important exhibition to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Flash’ Review: Electric Company
description: In the latest DC Comics blowout, Ezra Miller suits up as the speedy superhero alongside special guests like Batman (hello, Michael Keaton).
content: The Flash, the latest DC Comics superhero to get his very own big show, isn’t the outfit’s usual brooding heavyweight. He’s neither an old-style god nor new (a.k.a. a billionaire), but an electrified nerd who joined the super-ranks by accident, not by birthright or by design. Out of uniform, he is a normie, a goof and kind of endearing. He’s really, really fast on his feet, you bet. But what makes him pop onscreen is that when things go bigger and grimmer here, as they invariably do in blowouts of this type, he retains a playful weightlessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Justin Porter
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Blinken Heads to China
description: Plus, South Korea’s climate-conscious approach to food waste.
content: Secretary of State Antony Blinken is flying to China tomorrow for his first visit as the top U.S. diplomat. Both governments hope his visit will lead to trips to China by other senior U.S. officials during a period of rising tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: A Deflated, Low-Energy Trump, Now Twice-Indicted at 77: ‘Some Birthday’
description: He grumbled about his arraignment. He ate McDonald’s. Then he went back to his New Jersey club for an event that was a blend of a summer garden wedding and a political victory party.
content: Donald J. Trump went to bed Tuesday night, on the eve of his 77th birthday, as a now twice-indicted former president and current front-runner for the Republican nomination for the White House in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Batiste
title: Revisiting the Past to Change the Future
description: Who we are isn’t always visible, but it’s crucial to how we see the world.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Kevin Draper
title: Pros Won’t Be Hitting Golf Balls This Far Forever, Whether They Like It or Not
description: Players are objecting to a proposed change from golf’s rulemakers to use new balls, but the U.S. Golf Association said Wednesday it would not abandon the plan.
content: The United States Golf Association acknowledged Wednesday that it had heard ferocious opposition to its proposal for professional players to use balls that travel shorter distances — but it also signaled no interest in abandoning its ambitions to rein in equipment in the next several years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Kevin Spacey Hopes to Return to Acting After London Criminal Trial
description: The actor, who faces multiple counts of sexual assault, told a German magazine that people “are ready to hire me the moment I am cleared of these charges.”
content: Kevin Spacey, who will go on trial on sexual assault charges in London this month, told a German newsmagazine that he expects to be acquitted and plans to return to acting “the moment” that happens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Case for Ending Free Parking
description: Cities around the world are coming around to the idea that street parking is theft.
content: People waste time and gasoline cruising for free on-street parking. Some put chairs or traffic cones out to mark spots that they claim as their own. Fights over spots have ended in homicide. Delivery vans double-park because there’s no room on the curb. Garbage bags fill sidewalks because, again, there’s no room on the curb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Leaves Rates Steady but Forecasts More Moves
description: Central bankers have raised rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s, but now they’re taking time to survey how the changes are working.
content: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, skipping an increase after raising rates 10 times in a row since March 2022. Still, policymakers predicted that they might need to raise rates two more times this year as inflation, while moderating, remains stubborn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: Danny McBride Keeps It Righteous
description: The creator and star of “The Righteous Gemstones” has played a lot of hard-partying blowhards, but those guys aren’t him. Well, maybe the partying part is.
content: The party started early. Like, 10:30 a.m., still-drinking-lousy-hotel-coffee early. It was late March, a warm and overcast coastal morning, and all I knew of the day’s schedule was that Danny McBride, the creator and star of the HBO comedy “The Righteous Gemstones,” planned to swing by with a driver who would take us to an oyster farm, located somewhere among the islands and salt marshes of South Carolina Lowcountry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Sibling Was Abused as a Baby. Should I Share What I Saw?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the disclosure of a horrific event in a family’s past.
content: When I was a child, I witnessed my parent severely beat a sibling — a one-time incident nobody else witnessed. My sibling was a baby at the time, and the injury was dismissed as being the result of a fall. This occurred many decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: ‘Do You Even Want Us to Exist?’ A Bank Chief Fights to Survive.
description: The banks at the center of the recent crisis, like Western Alliance, are engaged in collective soul-searching.
content: Every quarter for the past several years, Ken Vecchione printed out a spreadsheet comparing the growth of the bank he runs, Western Alliance, with its three principal competitors: First Republic, Signature Bank and Silicon Valley Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: American Ballet Theater Chief Resigns Suddenly
description: Janet Rollé, who had helped lead the company through the turmoil of the pandemic, stepped down a week before its summer season begins.
content: Janet Rollé, the chief executive and executive director of American Ballet Theater, resigned a week before the start of the company’s summer season after 17 months on the job, the company announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Plans to Meet With Top Chinese Officials in Beijing
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who leaves Friday, could meet with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, during a visit he had postponed because of a Chinese spy balloon.
content: The State Department announced on Wednesday that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken planned to leave on Friday for a visit to Beijing to stress to Chinese officials “the importance of maintaining open lines of communication to responsibly manage” the relationship between the two nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: PGA Tour Commissioner Steps Back After ‘Medical Situation’
description: The tour did not elaborate on Jay Monahan’s condition but said two other executives would oversee operations during his absence.
content: The PGA Tour said Tuesday night that Jay Monahan, its commissioner, was “recuperating from a medical situation” and that two of its other executives would oversee the tour’s day-to-day operations for the time being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Man Who Questioned 9-Year-Old Athlete’s Gender Spurs Outrage
description: A track and field event in British Columbia has engendered debate about transphobia in Canada.
content: A man who questioned a 9 year-old girl’s gender at an athletic event in British Columbia has spurred outrage in Canada after one of the girl’s mothers said the man wrongly insisted her daughter was either a boy or transgender, and demanded proof that she was female.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: World Trade Center Arts Space to Open With Music, Theater and Dance
description: A one-man Laurence Fishburne show, a Bill T. Jones premiere and a new take on “Cats” will be among the offerings at the new Perelman Performing Arts Center.
content: As the marble-clad, cube-like Perelman Performing Arts Center has taken shape at the World Trade Center site, questions have swirled about what will actually happen inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Hosting Palestinian Leader, Xi Pushes China as a Peacemaker for Israel
description: In meeting with the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, Xi Jinping is pushing Beijing as an alternative to the U.S. for diplomatic leadership.
content: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, met with the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in Beijing on Wednesday, as Mr. Xi pushes to expand China’s influence in the Middle East and cast his country as an alternative to the United States for leadership in global diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Meatballs in Tomato Sauce Get a Little Lighter
description: Melissa Clark updates the classic, using fresh tomatoes and ginger for a lighter, brighter weeknight meal.
content: Meatballs in tomato sauce are a comforting thing, a ruddy, garlicky Italian American classic meant to be nestled on a pile of spaghetti and showered in cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Ryan Mac
title: Music Publishers Sue Twitter, Accusing It of Copyright Infringement
description: A group of 17 music publishers sued the social media company and said it was seeking as much as $250 million in damages.
content: A group of 17 music publishers sued Twitter on Wednesday, accusing it of copyright infringement on about 1,700 songs, and is seeking as much as $250 million in damages, the latest headache for the social media platform owned by Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Harvard Medical School Morgue Manager Sold Body Parts, U.S. Says
description: Federal prosecutors said the manager was one of seven people charged with being part of a network that bought and sold remains stolen from the medical school and an Arkansas mortuary.
content: The manager of a morgue at Harvard Medical School has been charged with selling body parts from donated cadavers and allowing buyers to come to the morgue to choose which parts they wanted, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Cormac McCarthy, Riding Into a Bloodred Sunset
description: He was the last of a generational cohort of writers who redefined American prose.
content: A page of Cormac McCarthy might sometimes be taken for poetry or scripture: the lean lines; the sparse punctuation; the jagged right-hand margin. The diction, especially in the books that followed “Blood Meridian” (1985), is both austere and lyrical, stripped of the busy noise of modern life and tuned to elemental, metaphysical frequencies. Even at its most idiomatically precise — gerunds with dropped g’s, “could of” for “could have,” “it was” instead of “there was” — his language can feel timeless:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Every Trump Indictment Tells a Story
description: The former president's court cases may double as a road map to his presidency and his era.
content: Let’s assume, because it seems like a reasonable assumption, that we have not reached the end of the indictments that will be handed down against Donald Trump. Let’s assume that either the case in Georgia, where he is being investigated for election tampering, or the special counsel’s continuing investigation in Washington, will yield a prosecution related to his conduct between the November 2020 election and the riot on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Miles Ahead,’ ‘The Exiles’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Inventive riffs on the biopic, the movie musical, the classic Western and the celebrity bio-documentary are among the highlights of this month’s roundup of under-the-radar streaming movies.
content: Viewers hoping for a traditional music-legend biopic in the style of “Walk the Line” or “Ray” will likely be baffled by this portrait of Miles Davis from Don Cheadle, who directs, co-writes and stars as the jazz great. Cheadle eschews the cradle-to-grave approach typical of such endeavors, instead building his narrative around a tall tale of Davis and a music journalist (Ewan McGregor) attempting to recover stolen tapes of his latest album. This mostly fictional fabrication gives Cheadle the leeway to create a playful, unpredictable and unexpected work — a cinematic reflection of the music that made him famous. Emayatzy Corinealdi is heart-wrenching as Davis’s wife Frances, while LaKeith Stanfield and Michael Stuhlbarg stand out in memorable supporting roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Introduces Its First National Security Strategy
description: The war in Ukraine has heightened Germany’s sense that it has become vulnerable to new threats, but some critics said the strategy lacks detail.
content: BERLIN — Germany unveiled its first comprehensive national security strategy on Wednesday, an effort to address Germany’s priorities and ambitions in a Europe transformed by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Chang W. Lee
title: How South Korea Puts Its Food Scraps to Good Use
description: When wasted food rots in landfills, it pollutes soil and water — and warms the planet. Here’s how one country keeps that from happening.
content: Around the world, most of the 1.4 billion tons of food thrown away each year goes to landfills. As it rots, it pollutes water and soil and releases huge amounts of methane, one of the most potent greenhouse gases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: New Obesity Drugs Come With a Side Effect of Shaming
description: Wegovy and other drugs expose a social tension between a quest to medicate illness and a stigmatizing belief that obese people lack sufficient willpower to lose weight.
content: Eileen Isotalo was always able to lose weight, but always gained it back. Now 66, her first diet was with Weight Watchers at age 14. She went on to try one diet after another and bought so many books on weight loss that she thinks she has more than the public library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Oakland A’s Fans Protest, but Nevada Passes Stadium Bill
description: A day after fans engaged in a reverse boycott at Oakland Coliseum, the Nevada State Legislature approved funding for a Las Vegas Strip stadium.
content: On Wednesday, a day after fans of the Athletics gathered at Oakland Coliseum in a long-planned reverse boycott of the team’s ownership and its plans to move the team from the city, the Nevada State Legislature approved a bill that would provide public funding for a Major League Baseball stadium on the Las Vegas Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: In Legal Peril, Trump Tries to Shift the Spotlight to Biden
description: Donald J. Trump, who is under indictment, is trying to undermine the American justice system by lashing out at his successor.
content: Under indictment and enraged, former President Donald J. Trump — with the help of Republican allies, social media supporters and Fox News — is lashing out at his successor in the hopes of undermining the charges against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: The U.S. Open Returns to Los Angeles After 75 Years
description: The last time it was there, Ben Hogan set an Open record. This time, players will have to get used to a course few of them have seen.
content: Lights, cameras, championship golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: If Democrats Win Back the House, They Will Have John Roberts to Thank
description: The Supreme Court strikes a blow for democracy — and Democrats.
content: A credible case can be made that the Supreme Court’s decision last June to eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion was crucial to the election of a Senate Democratic majority later that year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: William Jackson Harper on ‘Primary Trust’: ‘I Needed to Do This Play’
description: The longtime New York actor explains why his character in Eboni Booth’s play about a lonely bookstore worker is closer to him than any other he’s taken on.
content: When Eboni Booth’s “Primary Trust” begins, William Jackson Harper stands alone onstage. His weight shifts from foot to foot; his fingers knead the air. He is smiling, but that smile looks as though it comes from a place of pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Frances Robles
title: Seeking Latino Support, Trump Raises Specter of Latin American Corruption
description: As he blasts the government’s case against him, Donald Trump is courting voters he will need to win — or jurors he will need to sway.
content: The day before former President Donald J. Trump was arraigned on federal charges, he gave an interview to Americano Media, a conservative Spanish-language broadcaster in South Florida, and described his indictment as a “regression” of democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Gardening Is Hard Work. Music Can Help.
description: Our garden expert shares the playlist that has helped her stay motivated while working outdoors — starting with James Brown and Al Green.
content: Stoked by the energy of Brown and Green, my garden took root some 35 years ago. It was James and Al who accompanied me throughout its formative stages, always there as I wielded a boombox and case of cassettes alongside my long-handled shovel and loppers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s Misleading Defenses in the Classified Documents Case
description: The former president drew misleading comparisons to others, misconstrued the classification process and leveled inaccurate attacks at officials.
content: Hours after pleading not guilty in a federal court in Miami to charges related to his handling of classified documents, former President Donald J. Trump defended his conduct on Tuesday with a string of familiar falsehoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Noise Can Take Years Off Your Life
description: A conversation with Emily Baumgaertner, a health correspondent for The New York Times who went to places as different as San Diego and rural Mississippi to measure the harmful effects of noise.
content: We’ve all been annoyed by the stomping of our upstairs neighbors, a blaring ambulance that rouses us from sleep, a dog barking while we’re on a Zoom call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Vegas Golden Knights Win the Stanley Cup in Just Their Sixth Season
description: The Golden Knights beat the Panthers, 9-3, to win the N.H.L. championship, four games to one.
content: The Vegas Golden Knights, born out of trepidation, tragedy and ultimately triumph, won their first Stanley Cup in just their sixth season, beating the Florida Panthers, 9-3, at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Markets Await a Fed Pause — but Not an End to Rate Increases
description: A breather in the central bank’s anti-inflation policy is expected, but still-rising inflation has investors bracing for another raise later this year.
content: S&P 500 futures are up on Wednesday as investors bet that the Fed will not change its prime lending rate, thanks to an array of unexpectedly positive economic data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Fox, Trump and Millennial Movement
description: To follow the impact of the indictment, it may be best to watch Fox News and not the polls.
content: After a big news event, I almost always get asked about whether the latest polls show an earth-shattering shift in public opinion. They almost never do, and the handful of polls since the Trump indictment appear to be no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asmaa Elkeurti
title: Spotted Lanternflies Are Back. You Should Still Kill Them.
description: The battle continues against the colorful bugs, which may be coming for your wine. Here’s how New Yorkers can help curb the infestation.
content: See it, squish it, report it. That was the spotted lanternfly mantra of summers past, and the striking bugs are back this year, despite New Yorkers’ best efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Quantum Computing Advance Begins New Era, IBM Says
description: A quantum computer came up with better answers to a physics problem than a conventional supercomputer.
content: Quantum computers today are small in computational scope — the chip inside your smartphone contains billions of transistors while the most powerful quantum computer contains a few hundred of the quantum equivalent of a transistor. They are also unreliable. If you run the same calculation over and over, they will most likely churn out different answers each time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A ‘Rubicon Moment’ for Donald Trump
description: Readers discuss news stories and columns about the ex-president’s indictment. Also: Affirmative action; a “new” Beatles song.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in Florida, New York and Tennessee
description: A Mediterranean Revival home in Sarasota, a 1789 house in Kinderhook and a midcentury ranch in Nashville.
content: Ralph Twitchell, a founding member of the Sarasota School of Architecture, a regional style of postwar modernism, and a mentor to Paul Rudolph and other midcentury architects, designed this house and several of its neighbors fairly early in his career. It is about a five-minute drive from the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art, and about 15 minutes from downtown Sarasota. Sarasota Bay is a few blocks away, and this house comes with a deeded boat slip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Barzilai and Christopher Lee
title: The Fierce, Flourishing World of Battle Rap
description: Battle rap is an art form and a sport, as well as an industry that has been slowly growing over the last decade. While there are proving grounds all over the country, New York is its epicenter.
content: On the eastern edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant — a Brooklyn neighborhood synonymous with hip-hop excellence — a tiny wellness center is tucked between a Pentecostal church and a real estate office. Inside its sterile, 800 or so square feet, there’s a wall of mirrors, stock photos of people performing various exercises and fluorescent lighting that makes the plastic plants in the corner look even more fake. On certain nights, one could be excused for thinking this is a waiting room and not what it actually is: a battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Come for Me’ Review: T.M.I. in Overdrive
description: In her autobiographical new show with songs, Catherine Cohen delivers a heightened version of millennial oversharing and confidence run amok.
content: Attending Catherine Cohen’s new show “Come for Me” is like being swept up by a tornado, or maybe watching “Fast & Furious: The Vaudeville Years.” The pace of her new comedy show is so unrelenting that by the time you catch your breath after a joke, three more have zipped by. Filming sex with her boyfriend? Listening to true-crime podcasts? Freezing her eggs? Entire acts have been built on less. But in “Come for Me,” the follow-up to last year’s “The Twist…? She’s Gorgeous,” Cohen spends just a few minutes on each, if that, and moves on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Rhode Island Investigates ‘Disturbing’ Behavior on Official Trip
description: A Philadelphia developer has accused one Rhode Island official of making racist and sexist remarks, and has said another declined to stop him.
content: It was a prime opportunity for a Philadelphia developer that had won a contract for a $55 million project in Providence, R.I., to show off what it could do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Here Are the Likely Next Steps in the Trump Documents Case
description: The federal prosecution of the former president should play out much like any other criminal proceeding, but against the backdrop of the political calendar.
content: Now that former President Donald J. Trump has entered a plea of not guilty at his arraignment in Miami, the criminal case against him will, barring an unforeseen event, settle into a traditional trajectory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
title: They Are Trump’s Aides and Lawyers. Now They Could Be Trial Witnesses.
description: The former president is surrounded by people who have provided testimony and evidence to federal investigators. He’s not supposed to discuss the case with any of them.
content: Throughout the inquiry into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified material, his insular world at Mar-a-Lago was rife with intrigue, anxiety and competing motives as investigators sought testimony and evidence from his some of his closest aides, advisers, lawyers and even members of his Secret Service detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jody García
title: He Exposed Corruption in Guatemala. Now He’s Been Sentenced to Prison.
description: The trial of José Rubén Zamora, the founder of a newspaper who was convicted of money laundering and sentenced to up to six years, came as critics say democracy in Guatemala is crumbling.
content: One of Guatemala’s most high-profile journalists was convicted on Wednesday of money laundering and sentenced to up to six years in prison, in a trial denounced by human rights and free speech advocates as another sign of the deteriorating rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Police Commissioner’s Abrupt Departure
description: City Hall’s management style is questioned in Keechant Sewell’s sudden resignation. And a judge appears to consider a federal takeover of Rikers Island.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the abrupt departure of the police commissioner. We’ll also find out why a judge for the first time appeared open to a federal takeover of the Rikers Island jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Silicon Valley Has a New Style Icon
description: Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, is transforming a black leather jacket into a symbol of the A.I. paradigm shift.
content: There’s a new tech titan in town and he’s preparing to enter the pantheon. How do we know?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Europeans Take a Major Step Toward Regulating A.I.
description: A draft law in the European Parliament has become the world’s most far-reaching attempt to address the potentially harmful effects of artificial intelligence.
content: The European Union took an important step on Wednesday toward passing what would be one of the first major laws to regulate artificial intelligence, a potential model for policymakers around the world as they grapple with how to put guardrails on the rapidly developing technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: L.G.B.T.Q. Americans Could Become a ‘New Class of Political Refugees’
description: Queer people and their families are registering the danger in some states and considering relocation.
content: Eleanor McDonough used to be a legislative aide in the Florida State House of Representatives. She was, she believes, the only openly transgender person working there. That was until the wave of oppressive, anti-L.G.B.T.Q. — and specifically anti-trans — legislation being passed in Tallahassee became too much for her to bear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Judicial Crisis Resurfaces as Compromise Talks Abruptly Halt
description: A bitter dispute over a planned judicial overhaul had calmed as political leaders negotiated. But talks were postponed on Wednesday, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu moved to disrupt a vote.
content: An effort to resolve a dispute over the future of Israel’s judiciary, an issue that has divided the country for months, suffered a major blow Wednesday after a dramatic showdown in Parliament over a committee that picks the nation’s judges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: What to Know About Eclampsia
description: The autopsy report for the track star Tori Bowie lists this rare and sometimes fatal complication of pregnancy.
content: On Tuesday, an autopsy report shared with The New York Times showed that the Olympic sprinter Tori Bowie, who was found dead in May, was eight months pregnant and in labor at the time of her death. She was 32 years old. The report identified complications of childbirth as the cause of death, listing eclampsia and respiratory distress as possible factors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Navalny’s allies get years in prison as Russia cracks down on dissent.
description: Lilia Chanysheva and Rustem Mulyukov are the first of the jailed opposition leader’s organization to be convicted of charges related to national security since the Russian government declared his group an “extremist organization.”
content: Two allies of Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, were sentenced to years in prison on Wednesday, in a sign of an escalating crackdown on dissent in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Meet the First Woman to Sail the ‘Voyage for Madmen’
description: Kirsten Neuschäfer talks about winning the nonstop, round-the-world Golden Globe race and the possibility of another circumnavigation.
content: The nonstop, round-the-world Golden Globe Race has become a banner of “retro sailing,” or “sailing like it’s 1968.” Entrants for the competition, which begins and ends in Les Sable d’Olonne, France, are required to sail small boats alone, using only pre-1960s-era technology — no satellite communication, autopilot, cellphones or radar. Courses are plotted using celestial navigation and a sextant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Donald Trump pleaded not guilty in federal court in Miami yesterday to criminal charges that he risked disclosure of defense secrets and obstructed the government’s efforts to reclaim classified documents he took while leaving office. The former president was booked but not handcuffed, and he did not have to submit to a mug shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Markowitz, Karen Zraick and Samira Asma-Sadeque
title: Dawn to Dusk on the Corner Where Bangladeshi Brooklyn Gathers
description: In “Little Bangladesh,” a growing community embraces tradition, and adapts to new trends.
content: The number of Bangladeshis in New York City has nearly tripled over the last decade to more than 100,000. New communities dot the city, and their growth has helped make Asians the fastest-growing racial group in the city, according to the latest census data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: The U.S. Is Paying Billions to Russia’s Nuclear Agency. Here’s Why.
description: Nuclear power companies rely on cheap enriched uranium made in Russia. That geopolitical dilemma is intensifying as climate change underscores the need for emissions-free energy.
content: In a cavernous, Pentagon-sized facility nestled in an Appalachian valley, thousands upon thousands of empty holes line the bare concrete floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump Campaign Says It Has Raised $6.6 Million Since Indictment
description: The total includes $2.1 million brought in at a fund-raiser on Tuesday, previously scheduled, after his arraignment in Miami.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign said on Wednesday that it had raised $6.6 million in the days after his second indictment — a substantial haul, albeit a lower amount than the numbers it reported after his previous indictment in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Jeffery C. Mays and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: N.Y. Police Chief’s Exit Is Latest in Exodus From Adams Administration
description: New York City’s top officials overseeing crime, housing and homelessness have stepped down. Critics say the mayor’s management style is part of the problem.
content: After not even 18 months in office, Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has lost one top official after another from his administration, a troubling and unusual exodus as the city is confronted by multiple major challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Off the Clock
description: In the wake of the pandemic, people are rethinking their relationship not just to work but to time.
content: I have sometimes liked to imagine the hours in a day, or a week or a month, like swaths of fabric hanging in a clothing shop. Some are coarse and practical, others stretchy and deliciously frivolous. Some are filmy, made to be worn with weightless ease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Soon We Won’t Have Enough Kids to Fill Our Schools. That’s a Problem.
description: And good solutions are in short supply.
content: The number of school-age children in America is declining. At least one reason is the falling birthrate after the Great Recession. And declining university enrollment based on a lower school-age population — which has been described as a “demographic cliff” — is something that some colleges are already grappling with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Kills Effort to Censure Adam Schiff, Aided by Some Republicans
description: Twenty Republicans voted to kill the resolution, which also called for a $16 million fine if the California Democrat were found to have lied while investigating former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The House turned back a Republican effort on Wednesday to formally censure Representative Adam B. Schiff, Democrat of California, for his role in investigating and impeaching former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Fed Left Interest Rates Unchanged, for Now
description: Also, the spotted lanternflies are back. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: For the first time in more than a year, the Federal Reserve paused its aggressive campaign to bring down inflation — and left interest rates unchanged. Fed officials, who had raised rates 10 times in a row, said that they were giving themselves time to assess how the economy would react before making further changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump Thrives in a Broken System. He’ll Get Us There Soon.
description: It’s a place where rules are for suckers, norms are for fools, truths are pliable and people of high character are banished.
content: What if Mitch McConnell, at the close of his scalding speech on the Senate floor blaming Donald Trump for the riot that occurred at the Capitol on Jan. 6, had promised to use his every last breath to ensure that Trump was convicted on impeachment charges and could never, ever become president again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: Allies Pressure Biden to Hasten NATO Membership for Ukraine
description: Some members of the military alliance want to set a timetable for Ukraine to join, though only after the war is no longer raging.
content: President Biden has taken every opportunity over the past 16 months to celebrate NATO’s unity on Ukraine. But on one key topic, Mr. Biden finds himself somewhat isolated within the alliance: when and how Kyiv would join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Battle Lines Harden Over Big Oil’s Role at Climate Talks in Dubai
description: The hosts of the United Nations global climate summit later this year aim to give fossil fuel companies a bigger voice, despite loud objections.
content: An unavoidable tension surrounds this year’s United Nations-sponsored climate talks in November: They will take place in the oil-rich United Arab Emirates, and the most important role at the talks is held by the man who heads the national oil company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Every Block Is Another Battle for ‘the Cyborgs’ in Ukraine’s East
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 14, 2023
content: “It’s normal to be afraid. If you’re not, you’re dead.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The Phillip Schofield Scandal Explained, From Daytime TV to Parliament
description: The resignation of a television anchor, followed by an admission of an affair with a younger colleague, has gripped the British media for weeks. Here’s why.
content: It’s not every day that Britain’s Parliament discusses daytime television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Robert Gottlieb, Eminent Editor From le Carré to Clinton, Dies at 92
description: At Simon & Schuster, Alfred A. Knopf and The New Yorker, he polished the work of a who’s who of mid-to-late 20th century writers.
content: Robert Gottlieb, an illustrious editor at Simon & Schuster, Alfred A. Knopf and The New Yorker whose deft touch shaped a bibliophile’s library of novels, nonfiction books and magazine articles by a pantheon of acclaimed writers from the middle to the late 20th century, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Pearlstein
title: The Genius of Leaving Trump’s Fate Up to 12 Ordinary Floridians
description: A jury verdict can convince Americans that a prosecution isn’t partisan.
content: Among the criminal charges now facing the former president of the United States, the most extraordinary are 31 counts of violating the Espionage Act, a century-old law prohibiting the unlawful retention of “information relating to the national defense.” Barring a guilty plea — the more common resolution in a case as strong as this — those charges will eventually go before a jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: These National Parks Are Welcoming Stargazers This Summer
description: Some of the parks have become popular dark-sky havens and are hosting stargazing events for people who want to marvel at the cosmic views this summer and fall.
content: It’s hard to escape the glare from big cities and metro areas to see all the wonder that the skies have to offer, but several national parks are looking to serve as better windows into the cosmos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google’s Online Advertising Practices Violate Antitrust Laws, E.U. Says
description: European Union regulators filed new antitrust charges against Google, which could lead to fines and orders for the company to change its business practices.
content: Google was charged on Wednesday with violating European Union antitrust laws by using its dominance in online advertising to undercut rivals, the latest in a string of cases around the world that strike at the core of the internet giant’s business model.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A ‘Soda Ocean’ on a Moon of Saturn Has All the Ingredients for Life
description: Using data from the Cassini spacecraft, scientists discovered the presence of phosphates on icy Enceladus.
content: Enceladus — the sixth-largest of Saturn’s 146 moons — has a liquid ocean with a rocky floor under its bright, white and frosty surface. Ice volcanoes spew frozen grains of material into space, generating one of the many rings circling the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: Affordable Housing Woes Paint a ‘Bleak Picture’
description: So many developments have been sidetracked or delayed that some experts expect a “production cliff” to hit in a year or so, meaning fewer new homes coming onto the market.
content: Erika Velez considers herself lucky. A 31-year old single mother in San Antonio, she had been struggling to find a place to live since last June, when she fell behind on rent and spent months bouncing between sleeping on friends’ couches and in her car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Yearning to Be a Father, but Still Waiting
description: For men struggling to become dads, the emotional toll is real — and often goes unacknowledged.
content: Since his early 20s, Curtis Stephenson has dreamed of being a dad. As the youngest of three kids, he watched his siblings raise his nieces and nephews and thought, “Oh my God, I want that,” said Mr. Stephenson, the manager of a wine bar in Ottawa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: A Beautiful Evening of Music Emerged From a New York City Sewer
description: New Yorkers gathered on the shores of the East River to hear musicians — aboard a barge and canoe — taking advantage of the unique acoustics of a drainage tunnel.
content: Larry Desgaines sat on a piece of cardboard atop a damp rock near the mouth of a large sewer drain in Queens on a recent Friday evening. “It’s a privilege to be here,” he said, without irony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and George Gene Gustines
title: John Romita Sr., Creative Force at Marvel Comics, Is Dead at 93
description: As an artist, he defined decades of Marvel storytelling and helped bring characters like Spider-Man and Wolverine to life.
content: John Romita Sr., the influential comic book artist who helped define the look of Spider-Man and his alter ego, Peter Parker, and who helped create some of Marvel’s most beloved characters, including Mary Jane Watson and Wolverine, died on Monday at his home in Floral Park, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Adopts a More Muscular Security Plan. Critics Call It ‘Weak.’
description: The country’s first national security strategy is an attempt to set priorities, especially since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but hard commitments were short in supply.
content: Haunted by its responsibility for World War II and Nazi tyranny, Germany embraced the pursuit of peace with the fervor of a convert. But on Wednesday, its government took an important step toward shedding that legacy as war once again transforms the European continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias
title: Southern Baptists Vote to Further Expand Restrictions on Women as Leaders
description: Delegates at the denomination’s convention approved a stricter ban on female pastors and rejected the appeals of two churches led by women to remain in the denomination.
content: After overwhelmingly voting to finalize the expulsion of two churches with female pastors, Southern Baptists voted on Wednesday to further expand restrictions on women in church leadership, potentially opening up hundreds of new churches to investigation and expulsions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Book About Owls, in Which Each Species Is a Marvel
description: “What an Owl Knows,” by Jennifer Ackerman, is peppered with fascinating facts, photos and superlatives.
content: While reading “What an Owl Knows,” by the science writer Jennifer Ackerman, I was reminded that my daughter once received a gift of a winter jacket festooned with colorful owls. At the time I thought of the coat as merely cute, but it turns out that the very existence of such merchandise reflects certain cultural assumptions about the birds: namely, that they are salutary and good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
title: No Charges for Israeli Soldiers in Death of Detained Palestinian American
description: Omar Assad, 78, was found dead after being held at a building site last year by the Israeli Army. The military said the soldiers involved will be punished but not charged.
content: Israeli military prosecutors will not pursue criminal charges against soldiers who detained and gagged a 78-year-old Palestinian American man and then left him unconscious in a building site shortly before he was pronounced dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: White Starbucks Manager Fired Amid Furor Over Racism Wins $25 Million
description: The company fired a former regional manager because of her race amid the fallout from the arrests of two Black men at a Philadelphia store, a federal jury found.
content: The episode plunged one of America’s most ubiquitous brands into crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Meg Oliphant
title: ‘Different Than What You Expect From a Los Angeles Golf Course’
description: Collin Morikawa, the winner of two major titles and one of the few pros with much experience at Los Angeles Country Club, guides The Times through the host of this year’s U.S. Open.
content: For much of Collin Morikawa’s life, the Los Angeles Country Club was a mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Relief Pitcher’s Journey From ‘Bulk Guy’ to ‘Guy’ to Star
description: Evan Phillips doesn’t have the name recognition of some other closers, but his devastating sweeper is a secret weapon for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
content: Quality relievers come from everywhere. Consider the two who reached 400 career saves last month. Craig Kimbrel was an early-round draft pick from Alabama, a dominant closer from his first summer in the pros. Kenley Jansen, from Curaçao, spent years as a minor league catcher before learning to pitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: He’s No Jack Kennedy
description: Sooooooo much Camelot nostalgia lingering out there.
content: Let’s just go ahead and say the quiet part out loud: Robert Kennedy Jr. — the nephew of John F. Kennedy, the son of Robert F. Kennedy — is a bit of a crank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celeste Moure
title: Jack Johnson’s Oahu
description: The Hawaii-born singer-songwriter and activist recommends some places he loves on the island he still calls home. And yes, surfing and music are involved.
content: Born and raised in Oahu’s North Shore, the singer-songwriter Jack Johnson can still remember a time when going surfing in Waikiki on the other side of the island was a bit of a trip. “When I was a kid back in the ’70s, that drive seemed extra long. It was mostly dirt roads to get there,” Mr. Johnson said during a video chat from his farm on the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Vegan Restaurateur and a Meat Connoisseur Find ‘No Ordinary Love’
description: Atlanta buzzed with Pinky Cole’s plant-based creations for Slutty Vegan, while Derrick Hayes brought Philly cheesesteaks to the South. When they met, they shared a deep connection despite their culinary differences.
content: Aisha Kamaria Cole, who goes by the name Pinky Cole, has been called a visionary and a provocateur. She also has a knack for helping meat eaters step outside their comfort zones at her plant-based burger chain, Slutty Vegan. Stepping outside her own comfort zone became a priority when she met Derrick Jermaine Hayes, the founder of Big Dave’s Cheesesteaks in June 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Lukashenko says Belarus has started receiving Russian nuclear weapons.
description: The move would be another sign of worsening relations between Moscow and the West.
content: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said on Tuesday that the country has started to receive nuclear weapons from Russia, a long-threatened provocation and the latest sign of the worsening relationship between Russia and the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Roger Payne, Biologist Who Heard Whales Singing, Dies at 88
description: His underwater microphones recorded “Songs of the Humpback Whale,” inspiring a movement that led to national and international bans on commercial whaling.
content: Roger S. Payne, a biologist whose discovery that whales serenade one another prompted him to record their cacophonous repertoire of baying, booming, shrieking, squealing, mooing and caterwauling, resulting in both a hit album and a rallying cry to ban commercial whaling, died on Saturday at his home in South Woodstock, Vt. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar
title: Investors Are Putting Big Money Into Japan Again. Here’s Why.
description: The Japanese stock market is up nearly 30 percent this year, far ahead of the S&P 500, as firms bet that changes in how companies are run might just finally last.
content: The prime minister, Shinzo Abe, stood in front of the cameras in 2014 and said he was going to shake up the staid ways companies operated in Japan. It was a tall order. Shellshocked by years of economic malaise that followed the bubble of the 1980s, Japanese executives had clung to the status quo for years. Raises for employees and returns for shareholders were scarce. The consequence was an economy that barely grew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Berlusconi’s Legacy Lives On Beyond Italy’s Borders
description: Silvio Berlusconi rose when political parties were weakened and carried on through a cascade of scandals. Leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro have had similar trajectories.
content: In a strange bit of synergy, both the indictment of former U.S. President Donald Trump and the death of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy took place this week. Berlusconi, arguably, was the O.G. of populist leaders whose political careers carried on through a cascade of scandals and criminal cases.
source.name: The New York Times

content: A strong and longstanding bipartisan consensus in Congress around providing huge sums to aid Ukraine’s war effort is beginning to fray as a pivotal counteroffensive against Russia is underway, and as Republicans bent on slashing federal spending gain traction in their efforts to limit or block future military assistance for Kyiv.

content: Aileen M. Cannon, the Federal District Court judge assigned to preside over former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case, has scant experience running criminal trials, calling into question her readiness to handle what is likely to be an extraordinarily complex and high-profile courtroom clash.

author: By Roger Worthington
title: I Pledged $1 Million to Plant New Trees. My Money Could Have Been Better Spent.
description: A recent study said preserving existing forests was more important than planting new ones in the limited time we have to slow global warming.
content: A few years ago, feeling the need to do my part to slow global warming, I pledged $1 million to plant a million native conifer trees, many of them in areas burned by wildfires in Oregon’s Cascade Mountains, to remove and store carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Most of that money went to reforestation projects on national forest land carried out by a nonprofit I began. The work was overseen by the U.S. Forest Service.

title: Cyclone Biparjoy Packs Strong Winds as It Nears Pakistan and India
description: Tens of thousands of residents along both countries’ southern coasts were evacuated before the cyclone’s expected landfall on Thursday. Flooding remained a threat in some areas.
content: Cyclone Biparjoy was crawling along the Arabian Sea with powerful winds and appeared to be on a path toward the border of Pakistan and India, where the authorities have ordered tens of thousands of residents to evacuate before the storm makes landfall on Thursday.

title: A Meteorologist Weathers the Storm
description: Judson Jones, a member of The Times’s Weather Data team, tracks how global weather patterns affect even the most remote regions. He’s been busy.
content: Last week, New Yorkers woke up to a hazy orange skyline. Smoke from wildfires raging in Canada had poured over the border, blotting out skyscrapers and making the air dangerous to breathe. At one point on Wednesday, the air quality in New York was recorded as the worst in the world.

content: Ivan Menezes, who as chief executive of the spirits corporation Diageo used his canny understanding of the drinking public to help the company grow into a global colossus, died on June 7 in London. He was 63.

description: In interviews, dozens of Democratic officials nearly all agreed that Donald Trump deserved his latest indictment, but were far more divided over whether the case was good for the country.
content: The satisfaction is nearly universal, but comes with a queasy aftertaste: Democrats are relishing the possibility that Donald J. Trump will get his comeuppance at last. But when the mocking laughter fades, in its place remains a much more lasting anxiety. What will this do to the country?

author: By Luis Alberto Urrea
title: Read Your Way Through the U.S.-Mexico Borderlands
description: The poet and novelist Luis Alberto Urrea thinks the borderlands are the most interesting book in the world, being rewritten every day. These are his recommendations.
content: I was born in Tijuana and spent much of my boyhood in a neighborhood — “colonia,” in TJ-speak — called Independencia. There was an ersatz European-style castle at one end of our street, a tamed bear living at the bottom of the hill, a madman next door who regularly got drunk and shot his pistola at the moon, and a yard with bananas and a tall old pomegranate tree. Sounds tropical. Sounds like Gabriel García Márquez. Doesn’t sound on the surface like the deadly desert, like the frightening shadow land of crooked policías and narco hit men.
